item.title: Using "for" loops
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

[quote=“fasthop10, post:6, topic:419807”]im not getting eveyones shitty critism yes this works, it loops through all id’s to check, it will only stop in the fist instance if the first one is true, seriously learn something somewhere ive done the research and have this working if the first in the int is false it will continue to loop through i know this because it works perfectly fine in the many ways ive used this method of looping. IT DOES NOT STOP ON THE FIRST INT . if you looked at exactly what it is doing you would relize that .

ps: the referance to the bones is an example just the best one i have its short and to the point and gets the job done.[/quote]
Holy shit you’re a fucking idiot. Also you’re not supposed to check for equality with i which is the variable representing the index, you’re supposed to check for equality with the int at index i in the array boneId (boneId[i] should do the trick). Now let me explain why I’m right and you’re wrong:

     for (int i = 0; i < boneId.length ; i++){
          if (item == boneId[i])
               return true;
          else
               return false;
      }

I took the liberty of the correcting the mistake I mentioned before. Let’s look at it from the computer’s perspective: first thing is, it will check if the item id is equal to the one at index 0 in boneId. if it is, it will return true. Otherwise, it will return false, which means that it will stop iterating through boneId, meaning that it will only check the first index.

Read full topic

item.title: Using "for" loops
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

[quote=“fasthop10, post:6, topic:419807”]im not getting eveyones shitty critism yes this works, it loops through all id’s to check, it will only stop in the fist instance if the first one is true, seriously learn something somewhere ive done the research and have this working if the first in the int is false it will continue to loop through i know this because it works perfectly fine in the many ways ive used this method of looping. IT DOES NOT STOP ON THE FIRST INT . if you looked at exactly what it is doing you would relize that .

ps: the referance to the bones is an example just the best one i have its short and to the point and gets the job done.[/quote]
You fail to use a foreach loop, you return false instead of checking all the rest of the iterations, and you compare the indices instead of the ids. Don’t explain something that you even don’t know correctly.

item.title: Using "for" loops
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

[quote=“ytuio9`, post:4, topic:419807”]OK let’s post this again because people never learn…

ublic int boneId[] {526, 536, 532, 592};

public boolean isBone(int item){
     for (int i = 0; i < boneId.length ; i++){ this loops through the boneId's to find a true statement.
          if (item == i)
               return true;
          else
               return false;
      }
}

This will only check the first index of the array.[/quote]

  • a foreach would’ve been much more appropriate for the situation, and his method compared the indices and not the ids.
private static final int boneId[] {526, 536, 532, 592};
public boolean isBone(int item){
    for (int id : boneId){
        if (item == id) {
            return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}

Read full topic

item.title: Using "for" loops
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

OK let’s post this again because people never learn…

ublic int boneId[] {526, 536, 532, 592};

public boolean isBone(int item){
     for (int i = 0; i < boneId.length ; i++){ this loops through the boneId's to find a true statement.
          if (item == i)
               return true;
          else
               return false;
      }
}

This will only check the first index of the array.

item.title: Using "for" loops
item.dc:creator: @fasthop10 fasthop10
item.description:
@fasthop10 wrote:

heres a few examples of how this works .

public int boneId[] {526, 536, 532, 592};

public boolean isBone(int item){
     for (int i = item : boneId){ //this loops through the boneId's to find a true statement.
          if (item == i)
               return true;
      }
               return false;

}

public int boneId[] {526, 536, 532, 592};

public boolean isBone(int item){
     for (int i = 0; i < boneId.length; i++){ //this loops through the boneId's to find a true statement.
          if (item == boneId[i])
               return true;
               }
               return false;

}

true deifnition

For loop. The most common use of .length is in a for loop test condition. For example, the variable i will go over the entire range of subscripts of the array a.

[code]int[] a = new int[1000]; // Declare, allocate array of 1000 ints, a[0]…a[999]

//… Assign random values to each element.
for (int i = 0; i < a.length(); i++) {
a[i] = (int)(Math.random() * 100000); // Random number 0-99999
}
//… Add all elements of the array a.
int sum = 0;
for (int i = 0; i < a.length; i++) {
sum += a[i];
}[/code]

Read full topic
